title.rendered: Find Rooms For Rent in Portland

content.rendered:
Home to the International Rose Test Garden, and Portland Rose Festival, Portland is not known as the City of Roses for nothing. But why the growing interest to find rooms for rent in Portland?

Related: 15 Best Things To Do In Portland

1. Getting to Know Portland

Portland, Oregon was founded in the first half of the 19th century to make transportation of goods via the Oregon trail more accessible. Later, during Second World War, Portland experienced great Industrialization, with excellent job opportunities and more people moving to the city.

Now, finding rooms for rent in Portland can be challenging as professionals continue to move here for job opportunities. While you get great amenities and comfort, cost of living makes it necessary to browse roommate finder apps in Portland.

2. Finding Rooms for Rent in Portland

You’ll find out early on that rent in Portland is not cheap, and the prices may make you gawk. However, most people suggest that you find rooms for rent in Portland for at least six months, before you decide on buying any property.

Find Rooms for Rent in Portland!

Top Neighbourhoods in Portland

  1. South Waterfront: Home to the Oregon Health and Science University, this neighbourhood has a mixed community. The Aerial Tram located here helps you catch a lovely aerial view of the city. Rent prices are quite high, so you may want to look through some of Portland’s Roommate Finder options.
  2. Downtown: The heart of the city, you will find Saturday Market’s, iconic structures and reliable transportation in this area. Whether you are a young professional or looking to settle down with your family, this area is worth a look.
  3. Goose Hollow: Located close to Portland State University, you will find both residentials and commercial buildings in this area. An eclectic mix of university students and young professionals, this neighbourhood is known for a quirky vibe.

Related: The Benefits and Conveniences of a Roommate Finder App

3. Average Rent in Portland

5. University Life in Portland

When planning to move to Portland to study, ensure that you keep a roommate finder app ready. Rent in Portland can be expensive; hence, most people choose to live with roommates unless they opt for University Housing.

Generally, there hardly any need to dress-up in Portland, making it ideal for University students. It is not odd to find people roaming around in their jeans and vintage tees, or their hiking outfit. Numerous events, fairs and the incredible food trucks in Portland give students plenty of opportunities to create exciting memories.

If you want to explore University options in Portland, here are the universities that you should check out:

  • University of Portland
  • Warner Pacific University
  • Reed College
  • Lewis & Clark College
  • Pacific Northwest College of Art

Related: How to Find a Roommate During a Pandemic

6. How Transit Friendly is Portland?

Getting around Portland is a breeze; if you’re moving with a roommate to Portland, you won’t have to worry about solely relying on a car. Walkable bridges, reliable public transport and the cycle-friendly landscape help make Portland an extremely tourist friendly city.

1. Walkability in Portland

With Nike and Adidas’s North American headquarters located in Portland, it’s no wonder that it according to Oregon Live, Portland is the 7th most walkable city in the US. You will have no trouble trusting your feet when you want to explore the city, as many of its resident do. The city is also filled with green pastures, which make hiking a popular hobby for most residents.

2. Roads/traffic in Portland

Unless otherwise specified, cars need to adhere to a speed limit of 55 mph or below when within the city limits. Drivers should be careful about watching out for bikes, as most roads have a shared bike lane. Ensure that you familiarise yourself with specific traffic rules, such as knowing when you can turn left or right, or using mobile phones with hands-free accessories. Generally, traffic may not be a big issue, however, most people prefer to use public transport than cars.

3. Taxis in Portland

As the city is quite compact, if you plan on relying on Taxis, you won’t have to fork over a large fare. Typically, fares start from $3 with each additional mile adding another $3 to the fare. You may also have to pay $1 for each additional passenger, so keep that in mind of you’re planning on travelling with your roommate in Portland. Uber and Lyft are other reliable options.

4. Public Transportation in Portland

Rent in Portland may be expensive, but the transport isn’t. The TriMet provides reliable transportation throughout the city. From bus routes, streetcars to MAX light rail, residents have numerous affordable options to get around the city. Owning a car is not a necessity in the city, with bus routes serving the suburban areas as well. All buses are wheelchair friendly, making them the most accessible and affordable option.

5. Airports in Portland

Just 9 miles from north-east Downtown Portland, residents can access the Portland International Airport via MAX Light Rail’s Red Line, shuttles, bus routes, or via taxi. The PDX is convenient to get to, offers free Wi-Fi, great food and tax-free shopping options. Passengers from New York, Tokyo, Washington D. C. and nearly 57 other cities can enjoy a non-stop flight to Portland.

6. Cycling in Portland

Portland has over 350 miles in biking lanes and is extremely cycle-friendly. Most roads have protected bike lanes and all drivers know to watch out for bikes on the road. With several bike share companies, those who do not own a bike can take part in the fun as well. When living with a roommate in Portland, you can also take part in the Bike Events take place throughout the year, such as the Pedalpalooza Bike Festival or Portland’s World Naked Bike Ride.

Restaurants in Portland

The food scene in Portland is diverse and eclectic. It’s not just about restaurants, but exploring different food carts throughout the city as well. Be prepared for incredible food, as several chefs have been recognised for their talent with the James Beard Award.

  • Paley’s Place
  • Portland City Grill
  • Le Pigeon

Cultural Activities in Portland

Portland is known for its “Maker Culture” and is a haven for all artists. From Jazz to Hip-Hop, you will find incredible music events throughout the year or visit a live music venue on any day. Take part in Art Walks or Pride Parades; you will never be bored in this city.
